road_name: Sik E dakh water tower Road
assessment_comment: An excellent bridge installation with thoughtful erosion control and re-vegetation efforts, including the burying of riprap. The channel was wide and well-designed, the structure was stable, and minimal riprap was used. Overall, an impressive installation.
dewatering_notes: Good amount of water and no sign of dewatering. Significant rainfall today and yesterday.
velocity_notes: Velocity appeared reasonable, with a low gradient effectively connecting upstream and downstream sections.
constriction_notes: The channel did not appear to be constricted, with a wide base and riprap that did not intrude into the natural channel width.
substrate_notes: Stone lines were constructed using angular riprap with good infill of natural gravels and cobbles between the rocks.
riparian_notes: Minimal riparian area outside the construction footprint was impacted, with impressive and thoughtful regeneration efforts, including buried riprap, coconut matting, seeding, and extensive planting. Planted species included willow whips, birch, hemlock, cottonwood, and potted cedar. Gitksan Watershed Authority collaborated with Seed the North to plant huckleberry, soapberry, and raspberry in the future. The site was seeded with what appeared to be clover and annual rye, with straw spread for protection.
flow_depth_notes: Flow depths were measured between 10â€“30cm, with deeper sections forming behind stone lines. Depths appeared reasonable for this straight riffle section.
stability_notes: The brand-new structure appeared well-built and stable.
revegetation_notes: The site had thoughtful re-vegetation efforts, including seeding, whip planting, and potted planting. Gitksan Watershed Authority planned to collaborate with Seed the North to plant huckleberry, soapberry, and raspberry at the site.
cover_notes: Minimal cover was present at this time; however, willow whips were planted horizontally over the stream to provide short-term cover.
assessment_comments_og: Excellent bridge installation with extremely thoughtful, erosion control, and re-vegetation, including bearing of the rip rat. Nice wide channel stable structure, and minimal riprap used. Impressive.

assessment_comment: This is a brand-new replacement structure, extremely well built with extensive embedment that includes numerous large boulders, cobbles, and gravel. The multiplate round structure is embedded nearly 2 m. Upstream, woody debris and boulder structures are cabled together for added stability. This massive construction project involved a substantial amount of fill extending 60 m downstream and over 200 m upstream. The site now offers migration conditions significantly better than before.
velocity_notes: Velocity appeared reasonable, with a low gradient effectively connecting upstream and downstream sections. The boulders placed in the culvert, along with cabled woody debris and boulder structures upstream, would help reduce velocity and enhance habitat complexity over time.
constriction_notes: The culvert diameter was wide (5.6m) and did not appear to be constricting the channel.
substrate_notes: The culvert had extensive embedment of natural substrate materials, including large boulders, cobbles, and gravels. The substrates within the culvert closely matched those observed upstream and downstream.
riparian_notes: Some riparian vegetation was removed, but it appeared to have been replanted with grasses. The riparian area upstream on the right bank remained the most intact and similar to its natural state. The channelized banks directly upstream and downstream of the culvert, for approximately 50m, were reinforced with riprap, with no apparent riparian planting or fill covering the riprap.If future work is considered at this site, additional re-vegetation is recommended, including planting willow whips into the riprap and increasing vegetation on the stream banks to improve overhead cover for fish.
flow_depth_notes: Flow depths were adequate, and at higher flows, deeper sections would likely form behind the boulders and chained logs.NULL
stability_notes: The structure was well built, with the road column extensively reinforced with fill. Road runoff areas along the embankment were armored with rock for added stability.
revegetation_notes: There did not appear to be significant re-vegetation efforts, as much of the riprap remained exposed and only grasses seemed to have been planted. More effort could have been directed toward re-vegetation; however, the overall condition of the riparian area was adequate. If future work is considered at this site, additional re-vegetation is recommended, including planting willow whips into the riprap and increasing vegetation on the stream banks to improve overhead cover for fish.
cover_notes: The boulders placed in the culvert, along with the woody debris and boulder structures cabled together upstream, will provide cover over time. However, overhead cover was sparse within the construction footprint, with no signs of vegetative planting to enhance cover.If future work is considered at this site, additional re-vegetation is recommended, including planting willow whips into the riprap and increasing vegetation on the stream banks to improve overhead cover for fish.
assessment_comments_og: This is a brand-new replacement structure, extremely well built with extensive embedment that includes numerous large boulders, cobbles, and gravel. The multiplate round structure is embedded nearly 2 m. Upstream, woody debris and boulder structures are cabled together for added stability. This massive construction project involved a substantial amount of fill extending 60 m downstream and over 200 m upstream. The site now offers migration conditions significantly better than before.
